Sept 4_ 20 cts to Mr Stevens
The Better [unclear] by Rev. A.C. Thompson  [Krumerdkin's?] Parable
Slice Clifford and her  my dream_- Hilda>. as [unclear] to Christ.  Have ou seen it?  S. S Union W.C. Richards 
Bruno & Harry's vacation  Abbott

46 [crossed through] 181 miles from Alton to Bloom.

   Alton                    Frank Leslies

On the bosom of Jesus I'd die, 
Where ever He wills it to be
In faith and in peace I would die 
Till [unclear] called me his glory to see.

May 5 1854,
Left Duquoin early in the morning for journey to New unclear. Fine day, pretty warm, reached Mr. Lemon's to spend the night. Scenery on the Prairies very fine. Beautiful swells crowned with trees, now & then a grove, some pretty unclear.
May 6, 1854
Started early for St. Lewis. Passed urbana [image] Papstown, Bellville [image] Illinoistown. reahed St Louis between one  & two  Went to the Virginia Hotel  Pleasant  room -good accommodation-   [unclear] sabbath. Not at church on oc --

count of Mayo__ [unclear] Rowley called in G.M. Isaac not Col Larson in eve at Plantain House__
May 8 Monday
Spent at St Louis also Railroad Business Keeps us__ Rode all about the city in Sl L.. Really a fine place  North part of city pleasant. some beautiful residences [unclear].  Rowley called again made some purchases for self &  baby __ packed up for a start in morning.  
Tuesday May 9__  
On the Wisconsin  Left St. Louis about seven.. Before ten landed at Alton and went on board  cars  on

Chicago.  The body of a young man named Churchill of Portland Maine was on board.  {unclear] drowned in St. Louis,  fell over board into the river after an evening spent in dissipation with bad companions,  What an offlitced  family __ death indeed to lose a friend in such a way __ [unclear] aboard [unclear]  bought [unclear] card.
Reached La Salle about nine  [unclear] slept all the evening .. Came down inclined plane just as we cam to La Salle.. crossed the Illinois river..  Rode to Hardy House in an old ricketty wagon over horrible rode__ 
Wednesday May 10
Bright morning__ left La Salle for

Chicago just after dinner and arrived there about half past five__ at Fremont House. House crowded room small, little Mayo tired and restless_
Thursday  May 11_
Spend day in Chicago Mayo required much care.  I was sick all the afternoon from imprudent eating at dinner I suspect.  Started about eight in evening in [unclear] on Mich. G.R.R. riding all night__
Friday May 12
Stopped at Detroit about seven  breakfast there off on Steamboat Bay City for Sandwich.

from Sandusky to Elyview on cars just at night.  Anne [unclear] met us at depot. Went to their pleasant home .  large brisk building pretty garden.  
Saturday May 13
Spent with Anne  In afternoon son's wife came in to tea. pleasant. time talking with Anne and the two daughters.
Sabbath May 14
Stayed with Mayo in site_ went to chh in P.U. Heard Mr. Bernard just from Line Seminary: very dull better P.M. Than A.M.  Church a fine one.  In good style out side & in, stone but with a wooden spire.Highly plastered [underlined] inside.  The Deacon's pew a good easy one

May 15 '54
Monday
Quite a visit all the forenoon; perhaps not quite so pleasant from the House repairing which is going on being obliged to go clear around the house to get from one room to an other.  Dr DeMitt is repairing & enlarging his house.  The old Dining Room to a large back Parlor & a fine new Dining Room.  Has a fine Bathing Room connected with their own room P.M. All 4 of us with Dr's horse & big carriage to ride all around the ville and out on Ridge Road.  Shopping as we came back.  
Purchased one Silver Goose .80

  "    yds. Diaper 
         "      "

P.M.
Baby not very well, some diarrhea, [unclear] to be occasioned by overdose of cold milk & sugar last night. Dr. gave it a dose of Laudanum & some Laudanum & blue [unclear] to carry in case it was worse.  To the Cars at 6.30 train,  Dr, & Anna & young Miss DeWitte.  Some waiting & leaving a shawl in Depot.  Mayo better.  To Cleaveland in about an hour & immediately on board the Steamer St. Lawrence, a very fine well furnished boat in all respects, Excellent State Room. Boat side by side with the Cresent City, of an opposition Line for a long ways, finally distanced.

Tuesday May 16 -
Reached Buffalo about seven in morning- went to Merchants House - Not very nice or pleasant in situation or within conveniences - Family of six - mother four daughters 1 son-in-law stopping then on the journey from Calais Me. to Northern Wisconsin whether the husband had gone before About twelve took cars for Lewiston.
May 17 Wednesday
Twenty five years old to day I am to ? to realize more the value and

the brevity of time__
On board boat_ Guallario_ lying in early morning at Oswego_ a fine looking town_- after leaving there obliged to be constantly on birth at the sea sick__
May 18 Thursday
Reached Montpelier about [unclear] where we left the boat
May 19 Friday __ Left public house in Montpelier about four__ took cars for Concord.  Time [unclear] about Dr.  small place but beautiful__ state house noble building -- reached 
Concord about ten__ saw Eleen [unclear]  Hired team

to go to Dunbarton __ got there to dine__ found all well and glad to see us__
Saturday May 20
Sabra Gracies came to help us_think some of taking her to trains_I think I would rather go alone__ than have any one_- she seems good & pleasant.  A number called to see baby --many Thunstron & c-
Sabbath May 21
Went to meeting in [Mr & Mrs?] Fuller [unclear] to stay Funeral Sermon.

Monday May 22 & 23
Spent forenoon in  [unclear] preparation to go to Maine.  Left house about twelve to take cars at Parkins.  Called at widow Parkins Georges__ Reached Portland about tem_- Went on board boat_ Daniel Webster straightway bound for Bangor_ Fine picture of Webster on board. rather rough. went to bed and was not sea sick {image[  Pleasant sail to Bangor --Lucy;s before dinner-- She could hardly believe we had come-- Saw {unclear] {underlined] final

Thursday 25 May

Isaac & Eliiab went to Milo Wednesday morn [unclear] here late to night = Horse sick and detained them  Isaas thinks he will not go till Monday_- f[unclear] called at the Crossings yesterday -

Saturday 27 May --
Went shopping in AM. with Mollie --She is good and kind & sisterly-- Isaac bought Shady Side (no not Shady [underlined] but Parish [underlined])  Wrote letter home [3 words underlined]

Sabbath 28 May--
I went to chh in PM -- heard Prof Smith --good sermon,  peculiar man wears long hair and beard.  Enjoyed [unclear] of prayer with Isaac at night very much.  Last Sabbath we are to be together for some time.
Monday 29 May--
Lucy & I [mended?] for Isaac in morning . went downtown with him-- got miniature taken for him purchased bonnet white and crape-- went to boat with Isaac--Said the good bye-- O how long the months will seem without him-- But fast the time flies at longest--

Tuesday 30 May-- 
Finished copying bills in acct. book--several on mayo's dress-- Read "Old Man's home" [title underlined] dear little book. Samuel caries baby up to bed--
Wednesday 31 May

[unclear] & read Parish Side.  Went down street after supper and found dress maker-- got new bonnet. Lucy cleaning house__ Percie not well, Mayo happy as a kitten __ I may be the [preserved?] in health-- Lucy can probably have a job Monday -- one where looks good & pleasant --and lovely--  wrote to Isaac.

Thursday 1 June- 1854[ all underlined]
Mayo one year old to day.  Dear baby- may he live to be a blessing-- a long, long time,-- He grows finely-- wish Isaac could see him to day --. Went down street and got a dress cut.. long time before we could find any body to do it-- Began to read Bible in [unclear]'
Friday 2 June--
Lovely day-- Seems some cold to me  Letter from Isaac dated Aston House May 30-- He is well but tired-- How tired he will be when his journey ends & will no rest even then-- He sent $5.00 receipt for a [unclear] Magacine to Samuel & Eliab--

Saturday June 3-- 
Pleasant -- went down town in P.M. with Mollie about dresses-- finished white [unclear]. Package of books & [unclear] from dear, good thoughtful Isaac-- came by Express.
Sabbath June 4--

On Thursday June w Mayo;s birth day  I began the Bible-- and read in course Communion day --I went in P.M. with Lucy--The Shepherd preached --"I am the resurrection & the life" (" O for a closer walk with God & I feel like exclaiming to night)

Monday June 5--
Home all day --- sewing on Mayo's sack  Wrote home.
Tuesday June 6--
Went down town with Maria to dressmakers and doing a little shipping-- letter at night-- from Isaac dated Niagara Falls
Wednesday June 8--
Wrote to Isaac-- rainy day-- Lucy makes me  offer. I think of Isaac -- She is like him.
Thursday June 8
Letter from Augusta to be married she is .-- rainy very.

Friday June 9--
Sewed in A.M. finished calico dress-- Lucy & Mollie went to make calls in [unclear]  I went and carried Eliab down to the stone--stayed there with babies for the afternoon --wrote to E Knapp
Saturday June 10--
Been down town spending money again!  I am afraid I am too lavish--  I am happy with dear friends here  O it is pleasant to feel that I am cared for by those Isaac loves dearest-- it is so pleasant to love them all.

and feel that love returned-- O let me be thankful--
Sabbath June 11
Home in A.M. to let Sabra go to chh.  Went with Lucy in P.M.  Heard the Shepherd [grow?]-- Not [unclear] in business diligent in business [unclear] God says let every thing that hath breath precede the Lord  man more says--let every thing that hath muscle dig. Those are the  ones who appropriate to themselves what God's gives to serve him with-- Like bank cashier who appropriates the vaults money of a bank to himself.

because his has seen it --& his hands handled it.
Monday June 12
Elisb keeps asking me wh. baby I think is handsomest, wh. I love best. Letter from Isaac at St Louis. All good.  Baby stood all alone some time and walked through entry, holding to my dress alone-- Went down town with Lucy-- Eliab brought home herring.
Tuesday June 13
Wrote to Isaac got ready to go to Milo-- read Father Brighthops  Letter from Anna.

Wednesday June 14
Went to Milo with [unclear] & Lucy & babies-- Sabra went in stage $1,75.  At Bradford to dinner pleasant ride reached Milo about five-- all glad to see us.
Thursday June 15 --

Went to Brownvill got there about noon-- Called at Mr. Sewell's on the way ..Went by, pleasant River. O so beautiful  bright fresh & green. Corry cried hard at night=

Friday June 16-
Went back to Milo in

P.M. called at Lee's He sorry not to see Isaac .
Saturday June 17--

All day at Milo & so went to make calls at village-- took tea at the [kilteneters?] Mother went with them__

Sabbath June 18--
All day at home with Lucy & Mother and four babies-- one of Albins & one of Sally riders--  read "[Euthanady?"] Rev Smith preached .. the wicked to be annihilated at death--

Monday June 19-- came back to Bangor nice dinner at a private house-- some tired at night, Sabra came in carriage with us  Letter from Isaac written at Du quoin  & mailed at Mt Hawkins  Letter from Home-- first I have received - all well--
Tuesday June 20--
Some rainy-- read Lamp lighter-- package of books from Isaac at night   Sabra sick new girl came.

Wednesday June 21--
Went down town-- Had letter & [unclear] from Isaac (Niagora Falls}  How good he is-- mailed letter to Isaac.
Thursday June 22__
Fine day -- company all day long-- Mr. & Mrs  [unclear] to dinner -- [both] Lee and wife to supper & spend night-- dear old people -- O for the faith & trust they have one [unclear] alone can and awake a truly happy old age.

Friday June 23
Went down street and got my dresses from Mrs Bagley-- walked down --got -Pea nuts-- got large envelops to send Isaac  cravats  & silk-- [uncear..] did [unclear] up ready after hemming the handkerchiefs- Read Lamp lighter.

Saturday June 24

Wrote two or three pages to Isaac-  Percie & [unclear] went up stairs alone-- made pea nut candy -- & lots of ginger snaps to last till Amie comes-- Mollie not well.

Sabbath June 25--
I went to meeting all day   It rained some-- went in coach-- Heard Mr. Smith very good sermon from "Let him that is thirst come [image] Commitient man in P.M. from " in his was light and the ight was the life of the world"-- Wrote home
Monday June 26-- 
Mailed letters home & to Isaac and cravats to Isaac-- Sewing on [unclear] dresses.

Tuesday 27
Finished Lamplighter-- read till one oclock at night-- It is interesting but not quite natural I think-- Shows ingenuity to the writer however--
Letter from home-- [unclear] Doubleday dead-- Sudden.  Let me not forget it-- even I walked down & back to hear Mr Hitchcock-- [unclear] According to the glorious gospel 1 Tim. 1.  Excellent sermon
Wednesday June 28

Went to see a ship launch (Bosphonus)  It went off beautifully-- I was glad I went-- A large ship rigged with sails spired is a fine sight--

Letter was good & long from Isaac-- O how I long to night to see him.  {Corry?] walked half accross the room today I wish you could hear {corry] laugh see his wee face up to mine and his tiny fingers in my nostrils-- He does all sorts of funny things now very [unclear] to Rency-- pats him & kisses him-- Poor little P.J. is not well-- I wrote to Augusta last eve  letter from Emile & Anne--

Thursday June 29--
Mr  Sewart dined here-- I wrote mother  [unclear] Began Corry's bonnet.  read Longfellow went riding with Mollie & Eliab-- then to meeting at Hammond St. Chh-- to hear Dr. Pornroy on Missions-- very interesting-- state of Turkey-- English aiding American Missions there in  [unclear] point of view  China putting an end to Idolating by revolution-- Christianity will triumph.

Friday June 30--

Mary gone-- new girl came I wrote to Isaac-- in the forenoon several home

Sent Sabra with the letter to mail
Saturday July 1

Corry fourteen months today-- I can but of being-- What shall I do what shall I read or study to make me better able to care for and instruct him.  How wise a mother ought to be! If I can but aid even our little Mayo to be good & to do good making the

world better  I shall feel that alone to be worth living for.  ( Made gingerbread for Lucy and helped about fruit cake-- [unclear..] for Anne's coming)
Dear Isaac all alone far away to night --yet not [underlined] alone -- Our Father is with him-- O let him be blessed in all things [three words underlined] and we [unclear] spared to meet.  
Sabbath July 2--
Not very well this day-- some diarrhea-- Went to church all day- walked down in morning-- Dear Isaac -- I long for thee to day to talk & read with me. When shall we have a home [underlined] -- It seems to me I should love to

sit queen in home domicile some tidy quiet spot with you for my Lord & govenor & king-- and little Mayo to make us both more happy by the attempt to train him for [unclear...] labor for our hands & our hearts--
Monday July 3  
Wrote home [image] to M.D. [Hunston?]-- [unclear] my new [unclear] dress and have all to do over again-- {jnclear......] Mrs Hatch called -- the lady [unclear] of "single & married" in Mother's Ass't--.

Tuesday July 4-- 
Very still day -- bells ringing in morn & at sunset-- an occasional  gun & can now attempt at fireworks in evening-- I thinking of fireworks at Portland two years ago-- and of Dear Isaac-- Letter from home at night-- George may be here next week-- Corry walked all about the garden -- pulled clover [unclear] and broke some prints--[image]

Wednesday July 5

Our wedding day -- two years are gone-- full of joy have they been-- wrote to Isaac and received a letter from him too--  going to move office to Du Quoin and stay there_- I read this [unclear]-- beautiful & good  Went riding with Mollie & Eliab-- Reading Golden Legend -- enchanting-- such perfect poetry--

Thursday July 6-- Dressed the babies for company -- waited till Boats came in then gave up [unclear]

[unclear]  Then she popped in all suddenly-- well & bright as ever-- Went riding with Elaib & Mollie-- Valley Avenue delightful-- Lucy gave me tablet-- beautiful--

Friday, July 7--
Went walking with Mollie young lady died by means of fluid filling  [unclear...]  Had callers-- Ms. Harlow came & invided Anna & her husband to tea-- said " I am coming to see you dear very soon" 1  Anne did not go -- Commenced Flower of the family loud to Lucy

Saturday July 8-- 
Went down town with Anna all forenoon-- Did up crochet work  Sarah Harlow called Mollie gave me collar
Dear Isaac-- I am happy but I feel as if something seems gone from my very self-- something I do not more than half live without__
Sabbath July 9
At church in A.M. Read [unclear] on Genesis.  It is good & interesting-- some things in it new & strange.

Monday July 10-- I decide to go home in one week from this day-- [unclear] home and told them so-- went to Handy's rooms with Dr. De Witt & wife-- O beautiful!
Tuesday -- July 11--Mr & Mrs Shepherd here to [unclear] with their daughter & Mr Smith--

Wednesday July 12--
Wrote to Isaac-- had letter from Isaac-- Just so it happen last week-- Went to Clatown.  in to the Mills and even to the Island in Batteau-- Saw Indians  There is a [unclear] Indian from Oregon teaching school there-- Uses Bible in spite of Catholics & the priest--  Little Mayo not well-- feverish  Dr De W.  says give blue kill  Lucy  & I both administer it at night-- respectively to Percin & Mayo-- I did it fearing & trembling--New girl came Ellen Mesh good girl we think

Thursday July 13

the Harlows family here to supper-- Mrs H. and her sister  born in Pembroke N.Y.

Friday July 14--
I called at Mr Crosby in A.M. went to grove in P.M. for mosses to make baskets-- delightful time!  Mallie gave me a collar-- Corry not well-- teeth troubling him-

Saturday July 15

Eliab came up in morning and we went to the big ship Bosphorus-- Hatten & I then to find a Dr to come and vaccinate babies then to the Library & to bet a milk bottle for the journey home back in season for dinner-- In afternoon number of callers.  Dr come to perform on the babies arm  -- wh, was found to be a hard matter with Mayo-- Percin was very quiet-- after tea Lucy & I called at Mrs Hatch's & Harlows--

Sabbath July 16--
To church in A.M. Heard Mr. Shepherd preach-- "God now commandeth"  [etc?] Best I ever heard him preach.
Monday July 17-- 
Started in boat-- Renotscot  at ten for Boston-- Elaib Anna & husband met me at the boat-- E. with [unclear] wh. proved to be raisins, figs and all manner of good things-- Anna put a pretty comidian ring on my finger = dear kind family.

Wednesday July 19
Father & Mother went to Pembroke. We had beautiful Sunset-- Cloud like a smoking  volcano with brilliant crimson background  Parents went to examination & not home till about ten-- Mrs Himball, U.S. Burnham came in -- Jenny went [unclear] up after school-- Sabra went home to see mother and get little Sally in morning -- II gave her [unclear] for shirt again at night. 
Thursday July 20 -- 
I regulated some -- arranged trunks & drawers-- Abram B. Called-- I called at Mr. B's to see Lirry Jr.  and at Mr Moss  baby's Wate & two Kimballs -- George cam at night'
[Unclear what is written up the side of the page}

Friday 21 July--

arranged shells & stones for parlor table with george.

Mrs. Kimball called with her sister.
Saturday 22 July--

Letter from Isaac for [unclear] from Bangor-- Wrote to Emilie to come to D, & see Lirse [etc?]-- Wrote to Eliab enclosed order for $100,00 from Isaac--

Sabbath July 23==

Stayed with Mayo  in A.M. went to meeting in P.M.-- Hardly seemed like home to me  to sit down stairs in the pew  see the house so thinly peopled read some in "Lady Huntington"

Monday July 24--

Rose early -- george Mayo & I went over to Concord --chiefly for a [daguerreotype?] of Mayo-- I mailed a letter to Eliab and a book to Samuel__ "Putnam's [unclear] Biography" - Mayo some troublesome at first to be left with george-- but very good most of time  --awarded finely with daguerreotype felt full of glad all the way home

that I could send so pretty a picture to Isaac--
Some kind-- Bought a carraige--$2.50.  Gave mother "Euthanasy" and a pretty [turriew?] & ]unclear]  got " flower of the family".

Tuesday July 25--

Covered the carraige-- O I wish I knew just how to treat dare Jenny-- God help me--  Letter dear good from Isaac-- little Mayo pleasant and happy-- O how I love Isaac and him __ the little treasure__prayed to father at night-- Mayo's tooth the third came to the light--

Wednesday July 26--

Took Mayo to see Mrs Bailey and Burnham Mr Burnham at home.  came from Boston to day-- Jenny blueberrying at night.  Sabra ironing-- read Telemaque to George  Capt. K. Fixed littled chair for Mayo  called at Capt Whipples & Mr. Saffords--

Thursday Jul 27--

Not vary well but Jenny not able to get up-- so Sabra kept baby & I got breakfast-- made fritters & then wrote long letter to Isaac and one to Mother and mailed daguerreothyp of Mayo to his Father__ Done before dinner a load off my mind--covered a box for music-- Laid down

and had a nap after dinner  Read some loud-- Feel troubled at mother's health  she seems very nervous and easily troubled & excited-- How careful I must be not to say or do ought to trouble her-- Jenny does not love housework and everything she does about house seems a task--  Had letter from Lucy and Mollie. 
Friday July 28--
Female prayer meeting. Mao went over with George to Capt. Whipples & Mr. Safford & Jenny went blueberrying with Sabra  I read aloud Lady Huntington  Jenny & I gather in beautiful moss.

Saturday, July 29-- 
George & rode at four and at five started for Manchester - We had a nice ride only cold-- Bought a chair $2,00  Motton for shirts linen for Bosomes [etc?]  Called at Mrs Prescotts and saw Mrs. Babb and Dr. & Mrs. Merril from Lockport Ills.  On way home called at Mary Hearts & widow Bailey's  Home about two-- Dinner then lay down-- Mr. W. Whipple brought Whorttesons E. Hatch called-- dear good she is-- leaves next Wednesday--

Sabbath July 30--
I went to chh in A.M. Mrs. Hatch called at noon to see Mayo  I thought father preached unusually well. Wrote a little to Isaac.

Monday July 31

Washing -- baked a little in morning-- Mayo found the bread dish and before we noticed him smeared his dress & apron and face from chin to eyebrows with dough [unclear..] his hand-- the rogue-- I washed windows and rubbed picture glass -- Mayo rather fretful--

Tuesday Aug 1..

Ironing-- hemming neck hanchief for george-- went to meeting in afternoon called at Capt Kimball's  long letter from Isaac-- Mrs. Parkinson called  Made green apple pies Knead gingerbread [image]

Wednesday Aug 2--
Wrote to Isaac  & to sister Almeda-- very warm-- Mao tumbled out of bed ast night-- no got hurt at all-- He tipped over inkstand & spilled ink all over himself.

Thursday Aug 3

Letter came from Annie mailed letter to Isaac and Almeda-- Went up to Mr. Colby's and [unclear] by Mrs Rogers who is sick.  At night rode over to Weave with George.  Anne not coming at all so I expected Mrs. Brown & Agnes to come in the evening  Mother told me after they went how they treated Mr Safford when he bought the house & farm --too bad.

Friday Aug 4--

Leaving for Jennie-- made basque-- went to ride to Mr. Stones at night-- pleasant call -- Read Huntington in evening-- Mr. Rogers and Kimball  worse-- The one in [unclear] health-- blessed be God--

Saturday Aug 5-- Busy day-- helping mother & Jenny get ready for Monday journey to Westboro--  Sabra home at night-- little girls came over to see Mayo--  He comes with a beseeching coo and takes a hand and leads away to whatever he wants & stops and points or looks up to it.

Sabbath Aug 6--

Tine breezy day-- I at home in A,M,-- Read Lady Huntington through -- interesting and useful   John home in good season this morning-- Sung evening hymn altogether at night--

Monday Aug 7-- 
Gather mother & Jenny all gone-- started about seven this morning-- John washing I baked pies & gingerbread [etc?[  took care of Mayo-- got dinner-- wrote to Mollie Went up to Mr Colbys-- E Allison called  [unclear...]

Tuesday Aug 8--
Sabre ironed in A,M, Just after dinner Uncle Rufus & Samuel came-- Mayo & I had picked beans for our dinner but all were eaten-- got uncle some coffee-- eggs, cold meat, & apple pie--Mrs Chamberlin [unclear] Miss Brown and Capt Whipple called before meeting.  S. Brown stayed all night -- also Uncle & Samuel-- pretty boy-- Sabra went to meeting and I stayed with Mayo & Samuel  Had letters two from dear Isaac one from Augusta W-- Mailed one to Mollie-- Sung in Evening with Uncle & George--

Wednesday Aug 9--
Tried to entertain Uncle & cousin-- made bread and gingerbread-- helped some about dinner-- about eleven Mr. Hasseltine came-- the teacher for the Autumn-- Select School-- The dinner-- so new to be at the head of the establishment made my head ache but resting  cured it.  Uncle & cousin left after Dinner-- about two George & then H. left for Pembroke-- I sent mothers shawl to her-- to be mailed at Concord.  J. Brown here at night-- Sarah P. & cousins  [fr. Cak ham?] called.  Sabra called at Mr. Colby's-- got some Porter.

Thursday Aug 10-- S. Brown left after breakfast I wrote to Isaac six pages to father and mother four last night-- shall mail both to day-- pleasant day but cool.  Some lovely in A.M. Saw a humming bird in the front yard-- dear thing-- I expect it followed us from [DuCorgn?] with some message! Letter for Jenny from  Frank Putnam
Friday Aug 11-
cut Marjoram & Sage-- In P.M. went to examination -- Out Doors with Mayo some-- David Kimball came home -- Fire in woods yesterday did no harm-- wind blew it away from father's boundary. All alone at night--

Saturday Aug 12

Pleasant-- Out in garden with Mayo-- How beautiful is nature What an ingeonious life to be constantly thinking-- What shall I eat what shall I drink & [unclear] shall the [unclear] How refreshing to turn away from these and talk to the lilles and the trees.  No letter from Bangor One from Emilie  She can not come to see Lizzie  Book came from Concord-- Jen's-- [unclear] Biography-- Mr Wiley cakes to see Sabra--

Sabbath  Aug 13

Pleasant and very warm-- I went to meeting in P.M. Very few out-- many went to Baptist in the afternoon-- Quite a full house in A,M,  Dea P. read excellent sermons from Oberlin Evang.  Text - in P.M. "The Wages of Sin is death"-- Impressive-- particularly at close--  Dea P affected to tear in reading-- Mrs Wiley here at noon-- came up with Mr. Miles-- Mayo sat 3/4 of an hour looking in "Songs for Little ones" in my cap-- he loves pictures.  How his father would love to see him--.

Monday Aug 14--

 Sabra large washing-- Had beans & green corn for first time-- I picked four ripe tomatoes -- first we have had-- I called at Mrs. Emerson's and Mr. Colby's.  Took Mayo with me--

Tuesday Aug 15--
Sabra ironed-- I took Mayo out doors-- read a little Posted some boxes for me & one for mother-- gave Sabra one-- Wrote to Abby Wilson-- Mary Ann B- brought up milk and came for my [unclear]  Samuel carried it to the office & Josiah brought

back four-- One from Isaac one from Westboro one from Lucy and one from Francis Hinckly-- Mr. Harrittin called with book and letter from G. making five letters! a feast truly -- Miss Emerson called also Anna Burnbon -- I went to meeting-- Mrs Clement sick & son too--Mayo fell down cellar -- was not so much hurt as his mother was frighten.

Wednesday Aug 16-- Wrote down to Isaac & some to father & mother-- Went  out and picked up apples that AEolus had blown off-- Sabra had a somber, thunder cloud- day but seems to have gotten over it-- David K. called & asked me to go over and see Mr. Mills and take supper with them  I did & took Mayo. Went in to see Sarah Jane-- [Orcutt?] was there. She better-- Mrs Brown and Agnes called at Capt K's.  Mayo pretty good boy-- School commenced with 21.  More coming tomorrow--

Thursday Aug 17--
Wrote to George-- Sabra made bread & a pie & Mayo ate whole tomato-- Now he is asleep-- What a darling picture he makes  I love to cook-- Mrs Hart & Edith Morte called -- Mary Ann B--brought the papers fr. office  Mrs. Chamberlin & Mr. Miles called & Lavinia Twiss-- Mrs. G. took my white quilt to finish-- Read of St. Louis riot--. Cut out three shirts-- walked up to the P.C. and called at Mr. Coldwells & [Rowels?] - Saw Mr & Mrs. Patrick -- found eight tomatos today--

Friday Aug 18, 1854

Mayo out and opening for himself new garden gate coming in with shiny  eyes and dress literaly covered with dirt.  He is like his father yes-- He even now takes work out his mothers fingers an then clasping one with all his own-- leads the way out doors-- Many a time has done this--  There is no resisting such importunity== Eleven calls to day-- Mrs Brown just at night with Mrs Chase & Stinson--

Saturday Aug 19

 About the house most all the forenoon getting ready for company-- Elizabeth Burnham & Mrs S.B. - came up to see me-- Seems lonely to night-- Dear Isaac how i want to be with him to night-- We can think of each other-- In a week parents will be home I suppose.  That will help the loneliness-- Began a letter to Catha--
I don't "get used" to this separation -- It is harder & more hard-- O I shall [unclear] when it comes to an end.

Sabbath Aug 20--
Went to chh. all day -- Is not very [unclear]  Just been singing  If [unclear] went by [image] Mayo  [unclear] small notes & interludes -- in such an energetic manner that on the [grow?] steadfast faces looking down from frames on the wall seemed to relax and put on smiles  good sermons preach today  Orcutt Jameson read this P.M. very well__ Next A.M.-- "the Just shall live by faith" This P.M. If any man sin we have an advocate within the [image] other [unclear] Excellent.[underlined]Gold dear Lirrie good bye  Thermometer 
after five up to 80 [degrees]

Monday 21 Aug

Agnes called and left envelopes-- Sabra washing made Bread pudding_  Mayo went asleep with a tomato in each hand-- I wrote to Augusta and to Catha--  and began letter to Sister Lucy-- Called at Capt Kimballs & Charks-- saw Choate & Jane Ferren-- Hannah has settled fever but seems getting along well--

Tuesday 22 Aug--
Finished letter to Lucy & mailed it with other two  Agnes called after five cts.  I gave her a Spanish coin (20 cts) for a quarter ! [underlined] Made bread and gingerbread-- Sabra ironing  Thermometer up to 90 before 12  Letters from Westtone from Mother & Jenny-- from Isaac & Mallie-- Mallie sent "Old Mom's Home"  Esq Ireland brought me my Certificate of Membership to Al. H. M. Society-- Will be handsome in a Frame.  Isaac must be there till January  May be longer-- Wants me to write what we [underlined] shall do 
[image] I think we must be together-  Mrs Colby Sarah wrote & E.J. Miles called

Wednesday 23 Aug

Made custard-- Sabra went home all day-- Mrs Rogers called also Mrs E. Rider and Miss H. Marshall--Mayo very good most of time-- Sewed a little.  Read Harper Some-- Sabra brought pint-- Sweet cream from her mother-- nice very-- I wrote some to Isaac-- four pages on commercial sheet- Wrote about going back -- leaving parents etc.

Thursday -- 24 Aug

Sent Isaac'a letter-- Sabra over to Capt Kimballs to help them I read beautiful piece in the Independent on Sun Sets-- {God?] hath made everything beautiful in it's time Etc.  O how often I have thought of it lately-- Everything is beautiful-[ phrase is underlined]  also read [image] on [unclear] He says some trees "stand to tell the world what God thought of when he first thought of a tree!  I think the dear old chestnut on the beautiful swells north of here is such a tree- 

Been [unclear] for excuse-- always when I sweep May,  Multiplies his [unclear] indefinitely -- at any rate I find a couple of them at every turn.

Friday 23 Aug--

Four years since dear H-- died & How fast they go !  Mayo ran out after a flock of turkeys following all over the field  Agnes told of the injuring of the conductor on the N.H. Central put his head out and it came in contact with a pile of wood and was crushed-- 

Baked bread pie & pudding and cookies-- Sabra had head ache-- I go out about the fields with baby [unclear] fevers and all sorts of girlish deeds I do -- felling as if I was no madame at all or even an "old woman "

Man called with books-- I subscribe for one on popery-- It half past eight the dear ones came -- I had about given up seeing them

We shall to him but he will not return to us-- [words along the side]

Saturday 26 Aug
I called at Capt Whipple's and Kimball's last eve-- sick ones no wonder-- Mother told me all she could think of about the cousins-- They have an unusually pleasant visit-- Little Mayo very happy- glad of company-- Picked tomatos for Father-- I did not know he was so fond of them-- We had a very fit sprinkling this A.M. George came home at night and Nichols his chum with him-- Father went over to [unclear] to exchange with Mr Damon-- We sung a little [unclear] go coat etc Nichols sister on her way to [unclear] Persia as a Missionary
Wrote letter to Isaac to at night. [words on the side of the page]

Sabbath 27 Aug
I went to chh. in P.M. Mrs Hastings here at noon-- Mr. Daman preached well-- In afternoon from "Simon _Peter said unto thee I go in fishing etc.  Theme " [Labora ?] duty"-- George & Mr Nichols rode with Mr Damon Father home before supper--
Monday 28 Aug--
Sabra washed-- I got dinner Mother & I called at Mr-Safford's & Capt. Whipples-- I wrote letter to Isaac  Mayo said papa sweetly and very plainly--

Tuesday 29 Aug--

Sabra ironed-- Jenny not well-- I about house all A.M.  Mayo all about taking care of himself--Saying papa[underlined] dear baby!  Calls in P.M.  E. honshall, Mrs. Chamberlin-- Sabra rode home with Mrs. C. taking trunk-- I paid her all--$17.00 paid her $12.00 before. Letter from Lorry telling of the birth of Mollies little one-- How glad I am all is well- No letter from Isaac-- first Tuesday it has failed-- can hardly bear it--

Wednesday 30 Aug--
Made bread & baked it.  M.A. Caldwell here to tea-- looks a little older than once.  Wrote some to Isaac-- Jenny better-- Mayo good-- Father cut his gum today
Thursday 31 Aug--
Wrote in great haste to Mallie and Lucy-- did not even look them over-- also to Isaac-- meant to have written more yesterday but company prevented -- I must tell them so next time-- been out getting tomatoes- It is a warm day Letter from Isaac at [unclear] Hawkins also one

mailed at St Louis with a curious daguerreotype  I conclude taken for Isaac but imagine the artist made [unclear] takes and put on some additional touches  Mayo said --bow wow- to it-- glad you sent it though for if you look so I want to see you so -- O how I want to be with you dear Isaac I want to be where you are-- That picture makes me want so much to see your very self-- I do love you for writing to me so often  I can not thank you enough even-- you have no idea how long I have looked at you to night = Ru

Friday Sept 1.
Read some aloud-- Read Madam Roland-- Do not some how feel very well -- want to be with Isaac-- like the new Daguerreotype better-- It did not at first look natural perhaps because of the broad over shadowing hat brim-- light coat-- some additional hair lines [last 2 words underlined] on the face-- but it seems a good picture to me now I should not like those mustaches on any one else and should like face just as well [last 3 words underlined] without them-- Rain all day-- gentle & refreshing-- all nature is glad and drinks joyfully--

Saturday Sept 2--
Letter came from George-- I got dinner-- I am writing to cousin Frances and to her Concord friends-- I wrote two pages at night to Isaac Mayo good boy-- I called at the two Kimballs and Mrs Emersons & Colby houses with advocate--
Sabbath Sept 3--

Father at home-- pretty full meeting-- communion-- duty in P.M. Faith Hope Charity-- but the greatest is Charity & Love [underlined] God is love.  Heaven is Love.

Monday Sept 4--

Went over to Concord--with Father and Jenny-- Went to Kimballs for Daguerreotype got one also of Jenny for myself-- Spent some $10.00 left Mayo with mother--dined at Mr. Smart's-- Some tired. home about six-- started in morn at seven.

Tuesday Sept. 5--
About house all A.M.  Baked four loaves bread & apple pies loaf of cake and bach of cookies--good success in the culinary line-- after dinner wrote to Isaac  [postponed?] day work and went up to office with them  Mail closed but I got Mr Stevens to take them. Letter came from Isaac and paid me for going ten fold-- alone one from Mr Finley of Groten telling of the death of his wife- I stayed with Mayo.. Jane and Mother went  to meeting  If Isaac could but hear Mayo talk to the picture - such soft sweet tones--

Wednesday Sept 6

Got all ready for company and they came not-- Read three chap in [unclear..] Had bread & butter dinner  gave Mayo tomatoes-- read again after lying down little while-- almost 100 pages out loud to parents-- find it very interesting-- makes me want to get hold of Scott's works again I remember the dusty volumes at Mr Keys and the pleasure they gave me.  Went walking== whole family-- [unclear] and all-- Mayo in his carraige. He saw cows away on a distant hill & began to moo--oo as he looked -- Came home, carried tomatoes to Hannah, ate supper -- got Mayo to sleep-- Mr. Hasselton called-- long talk on slavery with father read again from eight to nine

Thursday Sept 7--

Mr H. asked Jenny how her little boy did last eve embarrassing her very much-- Wrote to Hattin Foster-- Jenny to George-- I put in a few lines to him-- Mayo some fretful-- I out doors with him most all afternoon-- gathered some apples at night-- read some in Mrs. Stow's Sunny [unclear].
Friday Sept 8--
Called at Capt. K.'s carried over tomatoes to Hannah and a custard to Sarah Jane--Made ten custard for afternoon meeting in P.M.  Mrs George Parker called with husband  & boy-- very anxious to have me go there to visit--Martha Colby called in evening I read again loud Road to Mr. Mills and Mr. T. Williams.  Good point-- Peons grape &plums to eat and bring home--

Saturday Sept 9--

Made preserves -- plum & tomato-- fine success-- Letter cam from Mallie-- She is very well-doing finely in every respect--  also a letter from Isaac-- being mailed at St Louis it reached me to day instead of next Tuesday. He can not come till January  Wants us to decide about staying here or going out to him and write the decision-- Mr. Hasseltine came in to tea-- We like him much. Dear little Mayo went to sleep very quick -- is very good usually-- I wrote some to Isaac after the people had gone to rest-- My heart says go to him-- judgement tells me we had better stay home till Jan

Sabbath 10 Sept

I stayed at home all day cold damp day--

Monday 11 Sept-
Washed a little baked pies-- made gingerbread-- Went and got Mayo weighed-- 25 lbs- called at Miss Emersons-- Mr. Mark Baily called another long call-- A very interesting personage--
Wrote to Mallie in the evening--

Tuesday 12 Sept--

Wrote to Lucy -- mailed to Lucy, Mallie Isaac-- Jenni & I with Mayo went up to the office-- called at Mr. Abbots, Stensons Parkinson's etc.  Mrs Mills called here also Mrs Brown-- Letter from George containing account of drowned student.  Miss C Stark called & left apples & plums, butter ribbon for Jenny-- I did not feel a bit ashamed of dear little Mayo-- He looked prettier & healthier than any baby I saw  How I love him!  How I want his father to see him-- Mailed little shoes for Mallie with the crochet collars for her & Lucy.

Wednesday 13 Sept
Fine day-- but cool-- Mayo not well- Diarrhea rather badly-- made him fretful-- Father & mother & Jenny went to school in afternoon  I here with Mayo.  Then left- him and father took [unclear] to call at Mr. Marshall's-- pleasant call Mrs. Davis children pretty very-- Prepared tomatoes for preserving Read aloud Abbott's Napoleon to Father--

Thursday 14 Sept.
Made biscuit- and bread- Went to Mr Hart's and with Mayo spent A.M. Jane came down with carrage & we went to Mr Brigham's for the P.M.  Pleasant visits both--Father came after us in a heavy rain-- When I got Mayo undressed he lay on my arm and siad so sweetly- papa, papa, - as if musing about his father to himself-- dear baby-- how I do love him-- How I do love his father too-- in Evening read Napoleon B. Stitched some wristbands for mother-- A good deal of rain fell this day--

Friday 15 Sept
Mayo helped Jenny get in wood-- emptied the basket almost entirely by himself in great glee at his success--Still has diarrhea--

Br. G. came & a classmate named Mardin.  G, has been sick-- diarrhea & vomiting-- not able to study since Monday-- Carried home Tomatoes-- Was here to dine & tell  little past three-

Saturday 16 Aug

I did most of the housework to let J. sew some- letter came from Isaac & Anna.  How good Isaac is to write-- Anna supposes we are going West this fall-- Does not know Isaac is coming in Jan. probably- Man came from [the one?] for father to attend Dr Gilley's funeral at eleven on Monday--

Sabbath 17 Aug  Sept
I went to Ch in P.M' Father subj: this morning Profane swearing.  This afternoon "I will sing of thy salvation all the day long"-- Read independent & Doddridge's "Rise & Progress" -- Wrote some to Isaac-- Mayo some better. Sabra & Mrs Chamberlin in at noon  Read ten & eleven of Acts to day in French testament-- So did dear Isaac away on the trains
Monday 18 Aug- [Sept is written at top of the page]
Parents went to funeral of Dr Gilley-- Jenny & I washed Mrs. Stinson came to spend forenoon-- dined with us-- Parents home about three

Tuesday 19 Sept.
Mailed letter to Isaac.
Letter from Isaac - Mr. Porter come about two & stayed till meeting - reading evening aloud. L. Smith here to dine & to spend the night, Mrs. Kimball's grandson & Mrs. Stinson called - 
Wednesday 20 Sept.
Ironing some in A.M. Sewed some - cared for little Mayo most - L? in Eve. Mother  & I at home & I read Mistress Milton to Mother while the rest were gone - I really like it.
C how can I wait till you to see Isaac - How long - All my intimates have moved & one gone. There seems no one I care for much out of my father's dwelling. Is my taste improving or my comfort worsening as I sage. Mrs. Milton

Thursday 21 Sept--
Gathered apples-- a plentiful harvest loads the trees-- I only gathered the fallen ones-- Got ready to make a call with father & he went to find the horse and found him with but two shoes so an end to my ride for he must go to the blacksmith--Did a little marking with Jenny called at Mrs. Kimball's with Mayo to see the babies there but all were gone to H. Rider's to visit-- Everything seems contrary to our calls this day-- I would stop over to see Mrs. Brown but I suppose she has Concord company to entertain-- so I must wait till another day-- "Sunny U.?"in Evening

Friday-- 22 Sept
Mrs Colby called in A.M. Meeting in P.M. [unclear] Ireland here Mrs, Colby & Miss Emerson. Read in evening. 
Saturday 23 Sept

No letters to day -- except one from M.Colby saying she had a place for Jenny and wanted her to come as soon as she could. Father says with his usual [precipetane?] she better go Monday-- So I suppose she will-- I do dread to have her go very much but may be it is best.

Sabbath 24 Sept--

I went to meeting in P.M.  Jenny sat below with me-- & father did not approve-- thought she should either sit below or above all the while not be changing-- she sat with me last Sabbath also & he disapproved-- I like to have her company-- but suppose gather is right--

Monday 25 Sept--

Wrote some to Isaac-- and a letter to Francis Hinckley--  Long talk about Jenny-- We all hope she will prove to be something worth having sometimes. She has talent & we do hope will visit for

good-- She has to day gone to Manchester to begin a new [unclear] of labor-- and we can but feel anxious--
Tuesday 26 Sept.
mayo very cross I suppose [last 3 words underlined] it is -- for I know not what else can be the trouble-- I have been out doors some time with him-- now he sleeps.  I have been finishing letter to Isaac-- Letter from Augusta-- now Madam Walter--  Carried my letters to P.O.  went to meeting-- copied Jenny's piece for [Leycum?]  Mr Mills brought grapes & apples.

Wednesday 27 Sept--

I ironed some-- helped finish jenny's night dress-  Sabra & Mrs Chamberlin came to spend day-- I got dinner-- They washed the dishes-- Father & Mother visited Mr. Fenney's Two Misses Stinton & Miss Buntin called  Sabra & Mrs C. stayed to tea-- I went to the store with them  Mayo tumbled down the steps into the barn-- did not hurt him much-- grazed his nose & forehead slightly-- He had brought in the horses but  [unclear] & was trying to take it back to the barn.  Went in to Lycum Little Mayo crying for me when I came home-- clung to me with all his might

Thursday -- 28 Sept-

Took little ride with father this delightful morning-- wrote little letter to Albin also to George-- No letter from Isaac-- I walked up to the P.O. What can it mean? I am troubled-- suppose I must wait till next mail-- Wedding at two-- Mrs Bailey on account of little boy's sickness not able to come-- I was invited to be brides maid--so I was quite an unexpected

honor! With Mr. Baily!-- How strange  & curious it seems to have to have others fondling our baby-- hugging & kissing him -- running after him & jumping over him-- I love to see him-

Friday 29 Sept

All ready for Frank and she came not-- Mrs. W. Whipple came with her wee one-- H. Kimball called Miss Emerson with butter saying she would call the 3 3/4 lbs. 3 1/2 and instead of 25 cts. as at Manchester 17-- She favors her minister !  Ednin Stover here to spend night-- Mr. Hassiltine to spend evening.    New member of family arrived to day from L. F. Mills's -- Miss Kitty becomingly attired in a blk dress with white stockings and white bosom like all fashionable ladies at present day-- She will stay as long as she pleases I suppose just as did her predecessor

Saturday 30 Sept-

Miss Stone left about nine We made Tomato Ketchup- pint bottles three of-- Mrs Brown called - Letter from Isaac-- Lucy & Mother  O how good they all are  Isaac has had a little of the Ague [unclear] overdoing -- perhaps over eating fruit beside-- I wrote little to Jenny for Mr. Caldwell to carry-

Mayo Sixteen months old to day-- I went to meeting in afternoon-- Mrs. C. Brown & Little Helen there _ I was glad to see them-- read aloud all the evening to father & mother wanted to write to Isaac but thought I had not excuse for working on Sabbath

Monday Oct 2-- 
Mothers Birthday-- I wrote to Isaac Gathered beans for seed and also flower seeds with the help !/of Mayo  I must send Lucy Cypress Vine & Lady puff seeds-- In the garden are various marigolds four'o'clocks Portulaca nasturtiums Lady puff Hibiscus etc. 

Tuesday Oct 3-- 

I wrote to Isaac-- mother to Aunt Hannah her Bills here with lightening rods--Then to P.O. letter from Jenny -- All well & good-- Her room mate working for an education likewise  - Two pretty Dahlias in bloom  Straw color and red-- another bunch of geranium buds

Wednesday Oct 4 -

Just got room swept & garnished -- When Mrs Gutterman came-- She spent day and served for me.  I very glad Mayo feverish & wants to be in my arms constantly. was so yesterday afternoon  Frank told me much about Goffstown people-- We called at Capt Kimballs and went to Lyceum- She is going to have a book for me to read lent her "Flower of the Family"-  Rainy in A.M. but fine evening-- full meeting of Lyceum good discussion

Thursday  Oct 5--

Very pleasant early in morn-  Father went to carry Frank home and I went & took Mayo O such splendid Autumn [unclear] on the hills all about-- I wanted to gaze all day-- could not endure to turn my eyes away-  They would not be satisfied with seeing-- one time in particular in a tiny grove looked like a blame of fire all the more attractive that the trees about it were still green-- Does it not seem almost wicked to stay in doors more than is really needful when there is so much beauty to be seen without!?  And it only comes over a whole year. 

making Mayo [unclear]   [written on side of page]

Letter from Isaac! good! Good!  Father says Jenny & I get all the letter-- He and mother have hardly had one diner  I have been here-- Isaac sent "Hard Times" [title underlined] by Dickens
Friday 6 Sept-

Mayo much better-  Mrs. C. Stinson & daughter called in morn  I sewed some but [unclear] with Mayo-- Miss Emerson in the afternoon called-- read all the eve-- Mr. Colby gathering apples--
I feel very [unclear] to night-- at least so far as [duncarton?] is concerned-- maybe it wicked but--

Saturday 7 Sept 
Mailed daguerreotype of Mayo to Lucy. letter to mother and Emilie-  [finished?] "James Montjoy, or,  I've been thinking" by A.S. Roe  Wrote George to sent by  W. Hassalton and A. Merril-- Went up to office-- got letter [unclear] G- stanks called with plums & apples-- 
Sabbath Sept 8-  
At meeting in P.M.--Mr. Hasselton called at night on return from Pembroke and left me letter from G. He hopes to come over and spend Tuesday night with some classmate-- I read aloud about Ottoman Empire in Eve.

Monday 9 Sept-
Mother washed- I baked bread, cooke etc.  Fine sweets Wrote eight verses of something-- "Death in [unclear]" while about work in forenoon- by[unclear]- [unclear] it to the "Granite Jim"  Wrote to Isaac in the eve-  beside reading two chaps. in "Sunny Memories". Now I must to bed__

Tuesday 10 Sept-

I dreamed Isaac came on little wicked black Dish - but when I awoke "behold it was a dream"-  I carried a letter to him to the P.O. and received one from him.. Glad was I .  and he is well too, and he wants to see his [Nettin?] & Mayo beside-  Called at Mr. Safford's to see baby -- just arrived George came about four  Quite a full meeting in Evening-- Much talk about Christians duty- O is it not a great thing to be a Christian?  Do I know any thing about it? [No?]  Mayo a new tooth-- the fourth

Wednesday 11 Sept-  
Mayo very well & funny-- I just sent him back to the study with father big rubbers that he had brought out and nowhere he comes with a huge pair of thick boots instead! Pleasant but windy-- I was up in time to see the sum rise this morning! George gone back to school-- I went to Lyceum in Eve- very lengthy but good.  
Thursday 12 Sept
Father & Mother went to make calls in A.M. at Mr T Mills- Kimballs & two Buntin's -- In P.M. we all went by invitation to Capt Whipples-- Mayo excellent boy-- Had pleasant time Read Napoleon in the eve--

Friday 13 Oct,

I make Mayor's clothes some shorter-- an improvement-- I think -- Went to Mr Colby's in P.M.  pleasant time Mayo good as need be-- Read aloud in eve.

Sat. 14 Sept. [crossed through] Oct-
Read some in Harper and Oct. 12 Ind. pr. Baked bread etc

Miss Emerson brought beans ready baked with pork!  very. nice dinner we had of them-- Read of the wreck of the "Arctic" -- Raining all P.M. and evening-- Fine-- wrote little to Isaac.

Sabbath 15 [image] Rainy day I not well-- so staid home- and mother went all day-- Mayo good boy-- I read my French chapts. in AM.
Monday-  Mother washed I got dinner-- Lamb, baked sweet apples-- tomatoes etc, good! [underlined] I finished a little sketch about- Faith. [underlined]  Wrote to Isaac-- read all the evening--

Tuesday 17

mailed letter to Isaac with some half written words-- Krumaker for instance I must tell him next time how in haste I sent it-- Rainy much of the time.  I ironed some & baked bread & seed cakes.  Mother went to church meeting-- Achsa Brown husband & baby here to tea-- glad to see them  Father says baby doesn't walk so straight as Mayo! grandfather's pride about it I reckon-- reading Sunny Memories all the eve-- about the Alps Mount Blanc-- O how it makes me long to see at least our own Mt-- Washington-- I must see it sometime  [phrase underlined]

Wednesday  18--
No letter from Isaac yesterday-- In the morning I had delightful walk to Mr. Ireland's calling on the way at Mr Twiss' visited the old people in A.M. and younger in P.M.  Mr I brought me home-- Wilbon's wife & baby there-  baby just 22 days younger than Mayo-- born June 23-- To Lyceum in Eve-- 
Thursday 19 Oct- First snow of the season, early in morning hours  Sun melted it away-- and a fine mild day it has been.  I walked to P.O got letter from dear Isaac and was made glad at the tidings of his good health-- Alas a neighbors letter fr. distant friends brought not

such glad tidings-- death has been busy at his mournful work-- Our, dear Lirrie Hatch - how she is afflicted-- another sister gone Annie who was to be such a joy and helper to them in school and at home-- O how my[unclear}!  A wedding here this Eve--  (H.A. Kimball & Hiram Steward)-- So do the joyous & the sad follow each other--
Mayo says Ducoigne very plainly and kind-- Little girls [knowing?] him about to day--

Friday-- wrote little to dear E. Hatch-- Called at Mrs. Stinsons & Kimballs with Mayo-- Meeting in P.M. seven present-- very good.  Mrs. Grant Called -- Children came to [know?] Mayo--.  Father and Mother went to make calls north-- Mr. S, Burnham sick--
Saturday- 22 Oct  
Walked up to office mailed letters to Lizzie Hatch -- letter came to George [remainder of letter to faded to read]

Sabbath 23 Oct

I went all day to meeting-- Mrs. Raymond here at noon also Mrs. Harris-- Allusion to Anna B's death in sermon this A.M. very solemn indeed--

Monday 24 Oct.  Rose at half past three breakfasted at five and started with father for Concord-- Cold & frosty morning but fine day  At Concord by seven-- Called at Mrs Smart's --Saw Mrs. French.  Home by little past noon-- Spent some five dollars-- Mailed letter to G. Read some in Eve.

Tuesday 24 Oct.

Wrote to Isaac and Lucy-- Received from Isaac & Albina got dinner for the rest Mrs H Colby included -- She is the Sleeves longer [two words underlined] to one of fathers coats-- I went up to the office with the letters-- Went to meeting in evening-- very good indeed-

Wednesday 25 Oct.

Took soon cold and have head ache and a canker sore-- could be cross [underlined] as well as not if I had a mind!-- In the afternoon rode with father (after a nap).  to Goffstown-- called

on Mrs Steele & Allison-- saw Mr. Willey-Noyes Richards died-- came home after sunset went into the Lyceum about half past seven-- beautiful eve-- little new moon hung in the West--
Thursday 26 Oct-- Letter again from Isaac and one from Lucy- Percie better getting well fast-- Good!

I called at G. Kimballs and Mr Safford's-- Ellen Whittle & Letitia Stinson called here-- A lovely day warm as summer

Friday 27 Oct--
Sill warm and pleasant  We invited to G. Kinballs to visit with a company of the neighbors-- very pleasant time-- Mrs. H Willson Mrs Brown & Agnes called and I went to singing meeting in evening--
Saturday 28--
Thermometer above 77 [degrees] - Seems like western autumn  I made cake & in the morn Caght to write some, but do not feel in the mood for it today  Mrs. Ireland and daugher  & grandchild, Mrs. C, Kimball & Hannah here.  I wrote some to Isaac in eve--

The apple trees have seemed to bid defiance to the chill winds  & early frosts but even they are fading now and dropping one by one-- winter is surely coming-

Sabbath 29 Oct--

I went to chh this P.M. rainy day but still a full meeting- The blessed rain has come at last-- O for a Spirit Shower to make the dry bones live in this part of the great field of the world-- How much we need it !  I wrote some to dear faraway Isaac-- I want little Mayo to see him-- O how much

Monday 30 Oct

Mother washed-- I wrote to Anna-- Went over to see S. Wat about a present to Mr Hasselton  She mentioned it to the scholars and all accord-- They bring money tomorrow with the intent to purchase a shawl knowing that he has thought of purchasing one-- Read in the Eve--

Tuesday 31 Oct--

Mailed letters to Anna to cousin Lucy & to Isaac & received one from Isaac -- Went to meeting in Eve-- rainy during day-- cloudy eve-- not many at meeting-- wrote a short peice for Lyceum True Beauty [title underlined] - after nine oclock

Wednesday Nov 1--
Mayo 17 months old-- Mother went to Concord-- started at seven and I went to [unclear] Parker's- and spent the day.  copied my piece for paper. Sarah Parker [Editness?]-- Called at James Mill's - very pleasant visit.  came up with Ingersol, Louise & Sarah to Lyceum-- Mayo good as could be all day-- I went to Lyceum-- and heard K.C. Sanborn Lecture on Dignity of Labor-- very excellent-- good paper too
Thursday Nov 2--
Mended some in A.M.-  Went to Lecture in P.M.  Mrs C. Kimball called-- and Mrs Charles Kimball after a shoe pattern-- Letter from Janey and from George and from Uncle Aaron's widow- Heard of Mr. Abbot beating his wife--

Friday Nov 3--
Finished Sunny Memories-  Old Mrs Baily & Miss Emerson here- Agnes called to show me the watch & cravat to be presented to Mr. Hasselton  Very well selected article & both handsome--
Saturday Nov 4-

Baking -- Agnes & Amanda Wilson & Sarah Wats came-- Amanda spent the forenoon working on Watch case-- Came in in P.M. to show me the article completed-- Nice [unclear] of snow to day  Fair but much colder than the last weeks have been  Letter from Dr Gilson-- he is coming-

Sabbath Nov 5--

Cold night. this morn - Then [found/] at 17[degree] below freezing point-  being fair & sunny- Mother went to meeting all day-- Mrs Raymond here at noon, talked about the report of her husband and the girl that lived with them  They all of course feel badly enough  Communion this P.M.  Sleep in eve. and did not read much-- began the Miss. Herald aloud-to mother-- Father about sick as he has been for some days-- gives up going to Pembroke-  So I must stay or go with Hasselton wh. I love not to do-- but I do want to go very much

Monday 6 Nov--
Mother washed- me cooked oven apples-- Amanda Wats with Miss Carr called at noon.  I trimmed  bonnet & finished Mayo's dress-- & wrote to Mrs. Smart- and a little to dear Isaac-- Give- up going to Pembroke or Concord It is a great disappointment
Tuesday 7 Nov.
Worked most of A.M. on apples went in P.M. to examination & in Eve to Rhetorical Exercises of Mr. Hasselton's- School-- Wrote Isaac & Josiah carried the letter & brought me a long one from Isaac-- all about the sad

accident to the train of cars-- He was saved- are we not glad & thoughful- I wrote a little letter to send as soon as possible to tell him how glad I am of his safety-- [Clear?] away night-- before we went to bed & father about decied to go to Pembroke
Wednesday 8 Nov
Father waked me at five to get ready for a ride to Pembroke -- but it began to snow before we started and was so rough & cold that he went to Gouson left me to return tomorrow

with the mail carrier and returned home  I went down town in afternoon with Mrs. Smart and attended to completion of my bonnet & some other matters for Mayo-- Went to hear J. C. Fletcher on "Our Country"  in the evening with Mr. Hadley-- Went home with Ann  Kimball--
Thursday 9 Nov--
Went down town to look for George found him not- Left word at P.O. for Mr Stevens to call for me-- Dine with Mrs Smart.

Friday 10 Nov
Reached home yesterday about three with Mr Stevens -- George came at five--  Little Mayo as glad all most to see me as I to see him--Baked this P.M. & George & I looked over last bh. of apples-- after dinner went with George & Mayo and called at Capt. Stinson -- T. Milsons and H. Rider's  Mayo at the last place behaved like a little[unclear] spoiled-- my call entivety, he stamped kicked and struck & all manner of naughty deeds he did--

Saturday 11 Nov

Letter from dear Isaac and one from Mallie-- Made an apron for Mayo  Read aloud to mother-- Isaac still well - How can I help thinking "My cup runneth over"-Bless the Lord [unclear]-

Sabbath 12 Nov-
I went to meeting all day mother not very well-- bad cold--Rainy very rainy all day-- I wrote two pages to dear Isaac  O how I long to see him--

Monday 13 Nov.
Rainy all AM and part of P.M. is cloudy to night-- Washed etc all AM- Wrote to Isaac-- We talked about Mrs Heman's Writings  I read loud in evening-- Mr Rogers & Colby set out apple & pear trees-- all bright out doors this eve-
Tuesday 14 Nov.
Mailed letter to Isaac  Father carried go to Goffstown to Institute-- brought home Pumpkin from Lewis Wilson's-  Fair day- After dinner called at Mr. Colby's and Capt. Kimball's -- got a pretty pattern for apron of Hannah Went to meeting in Eve-  Partly made an apron beside--

Wednesday 15 Nov.

Ironed four shirt & then plan clothes beside-- Miss H. Stark called and gave mother $10.00 and brought apples-- I napped after dinner  It snows began about eleven-- 

Heard news-- Letitia Stinson to be married thanksgiving also very soon Nancy Stinson.  Went to Lyceum in evening and heard Mr Prescott speak  Mr Ray wished me  to take the paper next week-- told him I would--  afraid I shall not read well.

Thursday 16 Nov.
Father wrote to Dr Gilson.  Letter from Dear Wingate-- G's school Monday after Thanksgiving-- Went to sing in eve-- Seems almost as if I were just as I used to be-- a free light hearted girl  but when I think of dear Isaac I feel I have a friend dearer then all these far away  I do long to see him .. [unclear] double [unclear] through
Friday 17 Nov-

Mrs Lilly here-- meeting in the afternoon-- Snowed a little in P.M. and then rain in the night-

Saturday 18 Nov.
Went to P.O. Letter from Jeney  I must tell Isaac that the little Mayo daguerreotype was the one I hesitated to send  Tell him too I want to see the Pigeons-- 
Sabbath 19 Nov.

I stayed at home with Mayo  House very full indeed-- I read aloud to mother from " lussinger" wrote some to Isaac- and some for my paper-- Mayo troublesome another tooth swollen-

Monday 20 Nov--
Mother washed, I hung out clothes-- we both ironed & cleaned house some-- We both got a little weary-- I have an [unclear] about all the eve-- written some to Isaac and some to Jenny I will not write to Bangor till another mail I think--
Tuesday 21 Nov-
Baked a little-- Mailed letter to Isaac-- Received one from him & one from Cather McKeen--Went to church meeting & to sing in the eve.  Mrs Willson & Chamberlin called spoke of helping Mrs. Mills Mrs T Mills called.   A number  of  pieces for the papers came-

Wednesday 22 Nov. -

Waked this morning to see the white flakes falling fast & ground snow  covered-- Snowed all day and some in evening- I went with father into Lyceum but only to hear the adjournment - So my paper comes next week-- G. wanted us to go to hear Mr. Tillstson lecture this eve, but father unable 

Thursday 23 Nov-  Beautiful day, but warm & throwing snow away. I must remember to tell Isaac to bring Sunny Memories for Jane, Mayo's double tooth through today-- George home just afternoon- [Slash?] six apple pies-- went to Goffstown

in the eve & heard Mr. Jonathan Termey Lecture-- called at Mr Allison's -- fine sleigh ride home little new moon & bright starlight again- home at Eleven saw the Hadley's could hardly get away from them  Subj. of Lecture-- "Hindrances to the Teacher's Success"  Good matter but not good manner- Mayo's double tooth through'  
Friday 24 Nov.
Warm and misty--Snow going fast.  Jenney came about three-- bad cold she has glad to be home again -- will stay two weeks-- she looks frail.  I am afraid she will wear out soon if not careful--I think it better should be where she is than at school constantly-- she would study too hard and kill herself.

Saturday 25 Nov--

Snow all gone & grass green as if Spring had come before her time-  A bright warm sunny afternoon this has been-- We have all been sewing-- read a very little-- O if my Isaac were only here George here, & Jenny here & we are all happy only I keep thinking of Isaac and wishing he were here too.

Sabbath 26 Nov-

I went to meeting all say-- Mrs Loveland & husband here at noon.  A fine day.

Monday 27 Nov 
Mother washed -- I baked seven pumpkin pies-- and a loaf of cake-- George gone to Bow & Pembroke-- pleasant day-- I very weary at night-- wrote to Lucy- Jenney wrote for my paper with reference to Annie Burnham-- Mayo says when I ask if he wants to see father "da da".. Mr. Wilson brought a pair of chickens, also Mr Stone-- 
Tuesday 28 Nov.--
Mailed letter to Isaac & to Lucy- Ironed in A,M. Father went to make calls and took my letters. Sent Mistress Milton to Lucy-  Received a dear letter ten dollars enclosed from Isaac.. Says he will be here in about a month he thinks- Good!

Wednesday Nov 29--

Capt Whippe brought a chicken. The baked bread and plum pudding & chicken pie-- It snowed all the day after about nine o'clock- very fast round towards night-- & snowed all eve.  No Lyceum.  George came fr, Concord on foot.  I finished my dress.  

Thursday Nov. 30  Thanksgiving--
I feel like writing straightway to Isaac to tell him how glad I am he can come in a month-- The day has been quite pleasant-- very few at meeting.  Mr. Howard came for us-- I sat up stairs to Sing. Uncle Rufus did not come

Mr Leonard Sarken preached a splendid discourse-  "He crowned the year with his goodness"- Mrs. Amenson dined with us-- 
Father & mother went to wedding had fine time there- great many present-- When they come home pony got frightened at a man with a pig in the road and kicked an broke the sleight to pieces-- they stopped and took Lewis Wilson's sleight & started again-- went a few rods when the same scene was acted over- Mother had to walk back to L Wilson's & wait for Mr. Saffard who brought her home-- Father & Mother both tired out- but both safe &  [unclear] well!

How thankful we should be God is good-- George going in the morning. I have been mending for him this evening  Wonder what Isaac is doing? 
Friday Dec 1, 1854
Dear Isaac coming in a month  It seems as if I should fly to think of it-- My prayer is that the Almighty may watch over and protect him that month & by the way that we may meet in health & safety-- So may it be--O happy day when he will really be here with me and our Mayo!

Fine day--  Father carried George to the cars and got his sleigh mended  Called by invitation at John Parker"s and went all over the house--

All in haste and order
Saturday  Dec 2--
Letters from dear Isaac  two of them and ten dollars in one-- I do not need any more money-- This is a glorious evening-- The moon is nearly full and shines on the pure white snow, and the stars are out and it seems like fairy land-- I have written four pages to Isaac & read some to mother--
Sabbath Dec 3
Snowing & blowing tremendously- There's danger on the sea-- Pleasant in morn but began to snow fast by noon--   Jenny offered to stay with Mayo so I went to meeting with mother-- Went into sabbath school and sat up stairs in the P.M.

Monday Dec 4--
How glad am I that we have shelter from the windy storm & tempest-- How many suffer already & O how it snowed and blowed last evening & night- The wind whistled and the poor flakes were driven hither & thither and piles up about the windows and doors-- Has been slowly but steadily snowing all day long-- I am some tired to night-- we had considerable to do baking and washing together
Tuesday Dec 5--

Tried to Mail a litter to Isaac and one to Mallie but Father could not get to the office  Glorious snow banks to day -- but it is fair-- only 9 [degrees] above zero-- I hung out clothes for mother-- made my fingers ache finely--

Wednesday Dec 6-

Very bad travelling-- people breaking out roads-- about forty at Lyceum-- I read my paper-- forgot to change the date and could not for a long time remember that it was Dec 6-- What a horrible blunder but it could not be helped-- I read Lamartine & finished "Raphael" - It is beautiful very--

Thursday Dec 7-- Snowy some & fair some-- I finished making a Josy from Mayo's blue flannel cloak-- Father went to Mr. Hart's and got a new horse & left Tammy  I called at Lewis Wilson's with mayo

Friday Dec 8-
Reading "Les Confidences"-- I am much interested-- I can afford tears over "Genevieve" & "Raphael"  over her swallowed up in the story but still I enjoy "Les Confidence" better  perhaps because I feel as if I were reading truths__Raphael is beautiful-- I wonder if it is fiction entirely-- I wonder if Raphael & Julie even were anything but creations of imagination  I should like to see one such face as Julie's -- [image] Cold to night-- 6[degrees] about zero only-- coldest we have had I made little shirt for Mayo this eve  Father took mother & Jenny to Mr. Ray's-- Jenney learned to make harness and thinks of doing it in place of weaving

Father & I ate dinner all alone-- It seemed lonely-- O how can I ever go away and leave Father & Mother all alone. I would take them with me if I could-- Mother particularly needs company-- being in poor health constantly, and unable to find much company in books because of her weak & diseased eyes-- I should like to be in two places at once so I might be here to be the eyes to my mother--

Saturday Dec 9-- Thermometer quite down in Zero this morning-- but has moderated some to day-- Jenney went to Manchester  Father took her to Paker's I dread to have her go-- It seems lonely-- we are only four now.  How scattered our little family will soon be-- O do not love to think of it-- Letter came from sister Lucy good & kind-- I love her-- She seems to love me but I do not know why-- She says they daily expect [Chartes?]-- O I wish Isaac were coming too so soon -- But it will not be long-- Not more than two weeks I hope-- We mailed a letter to George. Mr. Balch-- Frank -- [Colporteus?] here to spend night-- Young man & pleasant.

Sabbath Dec 10--

I at home all day with Mayo-- Mr Balch spoke in S.T.  Began raining in evening-- Show in prospect-- It will be impossible to explain this town at present for the bad travelling.  Mr Balch will try to employ Mr Mills to do it at his Leisure-- Read Doddridge "Rise and Progress"-

Sister Lucy writes to know if Mistress Milton's journal is truth__ I find from the encyclopedia of Eng Lit that it is true that the Port in IL 43 aged 35 married Mary [unclear] and that she left him in a month refusing to return-- He wrote three  books on divorce & was soliciting the hand of another lady when his wife reputed & returned & he received

her-- All true about the borrow £2500. and about his receiving the family of her father when ruined by the war--
Monday Dec 11 

Snowed all the A.M.  Mr Mills here to see Mr Balch-- The latter went to Concord in PM  all Fright & fair by noon-- Little Mayo sick-- cried about all the time after his nap until he went to bed-- Think it must be worms.  He was quite feverish by evening-- We rubbed him three times with rum & water and mother gave him little fever powder-- I tried to write to Isaac but had to leave it--because Mayo needed me.

Tuesday 12 Dec

Mayo is greatly better to day-- but not as well as usual quite. I wrote & mailed a letter to Isaac.  One came from him with ten more dollars-- I do not need it I lent father $25.00 when he bought his horse.  Dear good letter from Isaac-- Says possibly he may be here by Christmas-- I do hope he will-- Mr Balch here to dinner-- Mother went to meeting at the Vestry-

Wednesday 13 Dec-
Mayo continues better though he does not seem to feel very well__ [unclear..] to day-- I read in Dec. "Harper" -- Snowed some to day & blowed a good deal---

Thursday 14 Dec

Letter from Jenny and one from Alfred Pond__

A delightful day-- Mrs. Abbot here to visit all the P.M. Mother called on Mrs Peck when father went to P. Office-- Miss Agnes thinks Mrs. Metcalf makes a good deal of fuss about clothes!  Mother told her I had cut & made a calico dress since I came home.  Dr. Gilson arrived last eve-- called him twice to day -- has engaged the district school for the sake of becoming [unclear] with the people--boards at G. Kimballs -- quite a [sprig?] [image] agreeable man-- We hope he will decide to take up his abode here--

Friday 15 Dec--
Fair and mild-- Father offered to take me to Mr- Raymond's if he might return by noon-- I agreed thereto & we went-- fine ride and very pleasant call-- dined at 1/2 past eleven and home by one--very glad we went-- It seemed quite a relief to them both to [unbo?] some their trial to father-- both seen greatly to confide in him-- 
bundle came from jenny with print, boots, gloves, mittens for Mayo & paper-- Elastics & buttons on the bill but not in the bundle afraid may have lost--

Saturday 16 Dec--

Fair and warmer . 3 [degrees] above freezing until just evening when it grew colder-- I walked over to Miss Emersons  & Capt Kimball's-- Looked over thru on four barrels of apples for mother-- Letter came from dear Isaac-- How I do long to see him-- "By and by"!  I feel provoked to think how many believe the cruel standing about Mrs W. Raymond.  How quick some are to credit evil about another.  What a dreadful trial to the family-- How can they ever bear it-- and live under it--

Sabbath 17 Dec

I went to meeting all day-- Such sermons ought to do me great good-- How this poor world drive away thoughts of God--  Read "Pastor's Wife" to mother.  

Monday 18 Dec.

Snowy in A.M. but fair in P.M.  Washing & baking-- Father attended Rev. Collins Funeral at the Poor House. O how beautiful winter is .  The grand old hills and mountains are no less grand because snow clad.  The dark evergreens and the skeleton oaks & maples & birches contrast finely with the pure white snow.  Wrote to Augusta & to Isaac and 25 U. D. Thurston in Ere.

Tuesday 19 Dec--
Cold-- a little below zero-- Mother put out cloths and put down Pork-- Mailed letter to Isaac-- Augusta and M.D. Thurston  Letter came from Isaac & H. Newcomb
Wednesday-- 20 Dec

Starching & ironing-- In P.M. called at Mr. Nonsis, Colbys, and Watis & Burnhams-- Pleasant calls- all. I love some of the people here very much.. Beautiful day but cold

Thursday 21 Dec

Wrote to Lucy(sister)-- mother wrote miss Newcomb-- Proposing to her to board here next summer  Mayo and I rode to the P.O. Mayo said everything father did - "get up whoa", etc.  Mrs. C. Kimball called and wanted me to read the paper for her Saturday eve-- Only two days to prepare_  Wrote editorial this eve-  Letter came from George & Uncle Rufus-

Friday 22 Dec--
I made buscuit & cake- Mrs Miles and Mrs Caldwell here to tea. Cold very. Little snow too just at night. I got supper for Mother,

Saturday 23 Dec-
Writing for my "paper"- Read it in the eve- Letter came from dear Isaac  He cannot start till after the 26 inst-  so I relinquish all hope of his being here to the visit-- I'd about as leif not be here myself, as to be without him-- But that's naughty Nettin- It is all right-- If he only gets home, well & safely it is all I ask--
Sabbath-- Snowing all day pleasant in evening-- I went to meeting-- Mr. Streeter agent for the Jews, here to spend  Sabbath-- preached all day-- not much of a man he--

Monday 25 Dec-- 
Warm -- 3 [degrees] above freezing.  We have been washing & cleaning for the "Visit"- Christmas day-- Dont hear as much about it as I did last year-- Old Mr. Ireland quite sick-Gave Mr. Streeter $1 00 for the Jews. (Wrote to Isaac & Anna and to Guardian Soc, also to Mrs.. Smart-)  ( Got shirts from Mrs Willy Paid 1.25- for making.)
Tuesday 26 Dec. Father went to Concord I called at Miss Emerson's - carried her collars.  Went to meeting-- Father got under flannels for me Etc-- amounting to 2.40.  Letter from Jenny & Augusta--

Wednesday 27 Dec-
Rather stormy but mild I looked over apples-- rats, the wicked rascals, got into one barrel-
Thursday 28 Dec.

Not pleasant warm & misty- Mrs Rider & H. Kimball.. called  Father rode down to Mr. Ireland. He is failing.  Mayo & I rode up to P.O.  Letter from George, and from little Fanny Hinckley-  Lecture in eve by the County Comm. for Com, Schools  Mr. Barris of Concord- Excellent very-  The Dr, spoke also Dia P. is my [unclear] father! We had a fine time-- good many out.

Friday 29 Dec.
Snowing about all day-- Jenny came with Mr Safford   Nile remain till after the visit Wednesday-- Stay a week or more perhaps-- Wrote to George- a long letter about teaching.  told him what the "Commissioner"-said last eve--  Made four breads and one gingerbread to day- 
Saturday 30 Dec-
How can I wait for dear Isaac-- but I must-- Jenny & I went to the Funeral of Aunt P. Mills and in the P.M. walked up to the P.O. and called at every house in returning-- S. & M. A.  Parker here visiting-- Letter fr. Lucy

And Samuel-- so good Charles safely home-- Little Charley did not know him at first-- Sarah Parker will stay all night
Sabbath Dec, 31-- Last day of the old year I at home with, Mayo- a most delightful day-- Old Mr. Ireland died Friday night at eleven  Funeral Monday at one oclock 
Monday Jan 1- 18[image]

Monday Jan 1- 1855-
Delightful day - Father & Mother attended funeral-- All very busy preparing for the appointed Visit on Wednesday- L. Twiss came over for me in evening to go to the annual meeting of the choir, I went and enjoyed it finely- it was a very full meeting indeed sung from the "[unclear]" a new book
Tuesday 2. Jan-
Warm and a little cloudy- Mother went to meeting- I filled lamps, cleaned closets, washed cupboards etc- Meeting here in the evening-- two letters from Isaac-- can not tell certainly when he will come-

Wednesday 3 Jan--

Not storming and not exactly pleasant- In the whole a fine day for the visit- Somewhat over 100 persons here- house seemed filled-- as many as we ever had on such an occasion-- all seemed very happy

Our last Friday meeting was good one exercise seemed to me very effecting.  It was a prayer offered by an old lady just on the "border land" waiting for the "still angel to salute her".  She could not kneel but prayed [crossed through] trained her turn [unclear.....] the prayer was so earnest & childlike- full of faith & trust- It seemed to me I never felt so much the value of [hope?] in Christ above everything else.  Isn't it dreadful to see an aged person with no life beyond this world-- I do love old people dearly My grandmother & lived more than 80 years with us & died in her 93 year.

No one can be useful in this world who is not of it-- If it were not our duty to be of it, we may be very [lone?] we should not be in it--
Dec. 19- 1854

Have been all day to meeting and heard two most searching discussions to professed Christians-- They make me almost fear less I come short of salvation-- O Jesus is all my hope  How little I know of the great end of life-- ]unclear] might better be dead then living for aught but the good of the soul-- and it seems to me I live for almost anything else  but that - I am not satisfied with such living--

"O for a closer walk with God A calm & heavenly frame A light to shine upon the road that leads me to the Lamb" Our strength is not in ourselves were it what a failure our whole lives would be--
Should any thing occur to prevent it coming in this way-- perhaps would be best to send a check on Merrimack County Bank at Concord and I would immediately forward a receipt-

July 1854--
28
33 [underlined]
61
I received to day A letter from Isaac forwarded from Bangor  It contained the order which I enclose in this-- My first thought was that I should not [spend?] the money and need make no use of the order-- But Isaac is to be away so much longer than expected when he left that I may need more money than I have  Happening to think to night that if Anna and her husband come this way as anticipated it would be a fine opportunity to send the money I decided to write and enclose the order-- If Dr D. F. will be at the trouble to receive the money and give you a receipt therefor on my behalf it will much oblige me
